description: From French détente, from Latin tendō (“to stretch”).

entries.meaning: That which locks or unlocks a movement; a catch (stopping mechanism), pawl, or dog; especially, in clockwork, the catch which locks and unlocks the wheelwork in striking.
examples: A UHF tuner having 70 detent positions with fine tuning capability at all locations. Coarse tuning is accomplished via a toothed, detented disk and a spirally-extending rim having a follower lever operable therewith.

verbs.description: detent (third-person singular simple present detents, present participle detenting, simple past and past participle detented)

entries.meaning: The action of creating a detent mechanism to lock or unlock movement.
